Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effect of Local Corticosteroids on Dysphagia in ACDF Patients

Background: This study aimed to investigate the effect of local corticosteroids on dysphagia in patients undergoing anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF).

Methods: In this prospective, randomised controlled trial, 30 patients aged 20-80 years undergoing ACDF were randomly assigned to receive either 10 mg of local triamcinolone or saline solution prevertebrally before wound closure. The primary outcome was the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) relaxation pressure, measured preoperatively and at 1 month postoperatively using high-resolution impedance manometry (HRIM). The trial was conducted at a single tertiary medical center, with randomisation performed using a computer spreadsheet and allocation concealed from patients and analysts. The treating physician was blinded during swallowing assessments. The sample size was calculated to detect a mean difference of 10 mm Hg in UES relaxation pressure with 80% power and a 5% significance level.

Results: Thirty patients completed the study, with 15 in each group. The median postoperative UES relaxation pressure was significantly lower in the corticosteroid group (24.5 mm Hg) compared to the saline group (33.6 mm Hg; mean difference = -9.1 mm Hg, 95% CI -15.8 to -2.4; p = 0.01). No significant differences were observed in other HRIM parameters or EAT-10 scores. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Local corticosteroids significantly reduced UES relaxation pressure at 1 month post-ACDF, suggesting potential benefits in enhancing UES opening. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and explore long-term effects.

Trial registration: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT04717713.

Funding: Not specified.
